article.title: Great Slump (15th century)
article.text:
The '''Great Slump''' was an [[depression (economics)|economic depression]] that occurred in [[England]] from the 1430s to the 1480s.

==History==

The Great Slump occurred in England between approximately 1440 and 1480.<ref>Hicks, p.40.</ref> The economic slowdown began in the 1430s in the north of the country, spreading south in the 1440s, with the economy not recovering until the 1480s.<ref name=HicksP50>Hicks, p.50.</ref> The Great Slump took place against a wider trading crisis in Northern Europe, driven by shortages of silver, essential for the money supply, and a breakdown in trade.<ref name=HicksP50/> It was also driven by multiple harvest failures in the 1430s and disease amongst livestock, that drove up the price of food and damaged the wider economy.<ref>Hatcher, p.246.</ref>

The impact of the Great Slump was far reaching across England. Certain groups were particularly badly affected: cloth exports fell by 35 percent in just four years at the end of the 1440s, for example, collapsing by up to 90 percent in some parts of the South-West.<ref>Hicks, p.51.</ref> Prices of remaining trade goods fell dramatically as well.<ref>Hatcher, p.243.</ref> Popular rebellions ensued in 1450 under [[Jack Cade]], and the events contributed to the outbreak of the [[Wars of the Roses]] in the 1460s.<ref>Hicks, pp.52â€“54.</ref>
